questions.text: A woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome. 

Sheehan syndrome also called post-partum pituitary necrosis refers to the necrosis of the pituitary gland following significant post-partum bleeding, hypovolemia, and shock. It may present acutely as an endocrine emergency or present chronically.The late presentation has the following features:

  • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
  • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
  • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

Option B: Hyperthyroidism can cause oligomenorrhoea and amenorrhea but is likely to have symptoms of hyperthyroidism like weight loss, palpitations, tremors, heat intolerance, dyspnea on exertion, diarrhoea and muscle weakness.

Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed by a prolactin level >200 μg/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea.

Option D: Pituitary apoplexy is a condition in which there is a haemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland. This disorder commonly occurs in a pre-existing pituitary adenoma. This patient does not have any signs of adenoma and a history of PPH makes Sheehan syndrome more likely.

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Antigen binding to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I activates cytotoxic T cells.

The major histocompatibility complex (MHC), is a genetic locus that encodes a group of antigens. The MHC molecules also bind peptide antigens and present them to the T cells. The human MHC is called the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) complex.

The MHC class I proteins present their antigens to CD8 T cells (cytotoxic T cells). The antigens bound to MHC class II proteins activate the CD4 T cells( T helper cells). There is no cross recognition between the T cells and MHC classes. This is known as MHC restriction. For example, a CD4 T cell would recognize an antigen presented by a macrophage only if it's bound to MHC class II molecules. 

Other options:

Option B - B cells interact with an antigen based on the immunoglobulin surface receptors on the B cell. The receptor along with the antigen is embodied and degraded and the peptides produced are returned to the cell surface. It is then bound to the MHC class II molecules present on the cell surface. This is then recognized by CD4 T cells. Ultimately, the B cells are stimulated to proliferate and differentiate into plasma cells which secrete antibodies. 

Option C - Natural killer (NK) cells are granular lymphocytes that confer innate immunity by protecting against viruses and intracellular pathogens. 

Option D - T helper cells are responsible for the production of cytokines which activate the humoral and cell-mediated branches of immunity. These cells will recognize only those antigens that are presented along with MCH class II molecules on APC such as macrophages and B lymphocytes.

Related Pearl: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells and platelets

Mainly expressed on cells that present ingested antigens and respond to T-cell help (macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells).

Consist of a polymorphic α, or heavy, chain linked noncovalently to the nonpolymorphic protein called β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of a noncovalently associated α chain and β chain, both of which are polymorphic.

The α chains are encoded by three genes, designated HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded in a region called HLA-D, which has three subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display peptides that are derived from proteins, such as viral and tumor antigens

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and are typically derived from extracellular microbes and soluble proteins

Peptide-class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells, which function as CTLs.

Class II-peptide complex is recognized by CD4+ T cells

 

 

 

Image – MHC Class I and Class II molecules

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the hospital with fever, malaise, and arthralgia for a 1-month duration. She also complains of pain, numbness, and weakness in her right arm which has been increasing over the past 1 week. Clinical examination reveals weak radial pulses and her lab investigations show elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features with marked weakening of pulse in the upper extremities and laboratory findings of elevated ESR are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. It is also known as pulseless disease. 

Takayasu arteritis is a systemic disease and may present with generalised and vascular symptoms. It commonly affects adolescents or young females. Generalised symptoms like fever, night sweats, weight loss, malaise, arthralgias, and anorexia, may occur long before vascular symptoms.

Vascular symptoms depend on the vessel involved:

  • Arch of the aorta and its branches:
    • Subclavian artery (most commonly affected) - leads to weak pulses in the upper extremities. Hence it is also known as pulseless disease. May also lead to Raynaud’s phenomenon.
    • Carotid arteries- leads to weak pulses, blindness, and neurological deficits.
    • Aortic arch- may lead to congestive heart failure
  • Abdominal aorta, celiac axis and superior mesenteric artery- leads to abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting
  • Iliac vessels- leads to claudication of the legs
  • Renal arteries- leads to systemic hypertension
  • Pulmonary artery- leads to pulmonary hypertension
  • Coronary arteries (least commonly affected) - lead to myocardial infarction

Investigations:

  • Lab reports reveal an elevated ESR level, anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels.
  • Arteriography is done as a confirmatory test.

Treatment includes glucocorticoid therapy, methotrexate, immunotherapy with anti-TNF agents, and surgery. 

Other options:

Option A: Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital narrowing of the aorta, leading to upper limb hypertension and weak or delayed femoral pulses (radio-femoral delay). Patients may also present with headaches, nosebleeds, and claudication in the lower limbs.

Option B: Giant cell arteritis is a vasculitis affecting large arteries, commonly presenting with temporal headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and vision loss. It is often associated with elevated ESR and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue.

Option D: Syphilitic aortitis, a complication of tertiary syphilis, involves inflammation of the aorta, leading to aortic aneurysm, aortic regurgitation, or narrowing of the coronary ostia. Clinical features include chest pain, dyspnea, and signs of heart failure.

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

Vasculitis

Predominant vessel involved

Inflammatory cells

Other features

Temporal arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

Lymphocytes, and macrophages

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

Takayasu Arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Pulseless disease

 

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Microscopic polyangiitis

Capillaries, small arterioles, venules

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Churg-Strauss Syndrome

Medium and small arteries

 

Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: In patients with Wilson's disease, Kayser-Fleischer rings are most commonly associated with:
questions.solution:
The presence of the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring in Wilson's disease is most commonly associated with neuropsychiatric manifestations such as dystonia.

Wilson’s disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene on Chr.13q. The gene encodes a copper-transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions:

  • Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin
  • Helps excrete free copper in bile.

Thus, an ATP7B deficiency leads to excess deposition of free copper within tissues. It is an autosomal recessive condition. So, siblings of affected children have a 1 in 4 chance.

In the majority of cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations follow hepatic manifestations. It is due to the deposition of free copper in the basal ganglia (leading to bilateral degeneration and atrophy) and cortex. The features include:

  • Dysarthria (most common): Irregular word spacing, hypophonic or spastic speech
  • Dystonia: Vacuous smile i.e mask-like face with an open mouth
  • Parkinsonism: Bradykinesia, postural instability, rigidity
  • Subcortical dementia: Slow mental processing, memory loss
  • Psychiatric symptoms: Loss of emotional control, depression, hyperactivity
  • Decreased scholastic performance: Deterioration in handwriting, clumsiness
  • Autonomic symptoms: Excessive sweating and salivation, sexual dysfunction
  • Wing beating tremors (seen in advanced disease): High amplitude tremor that is prominent with arms abducted, elbows flexed and palms facing downward.

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency department one hour after spilling hot oil on his hands while cooking. On examination, multiple blisters are present on his right hand. The injuries are extremely painful when touched with gloves and capillary refilling is normal.  Which layers of skin are involved in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple blisters, tenderness over the injured skin, and normal capillary refilling time has second-degree superficial burns. The layers of skin involved here are the epidermis and papillary dermis (the upper part of the dermis).

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First-degree burns: In this, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (partial-thickness burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep.
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues.

Related Pearl: Wallace's rule of 9

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her 30th week of pregnancy undergoes a pulmonary function test. Assuming there is no respiratory abnormality, which of the following would be decreased?
questions.solution:
Functional residual capacity decreases in pregnancy.

The changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy are:

Increase

Decrease

Unaffected
  • Tidal volume
  • Inspiratory capacity
  • Minute O2 uptake
  • Minute ventilation
  • Functional residual capacity
  • Expiratory reserve volume
  • Residual volume
  • Total lung capacity
  • Respiratory rate
  • Vital capacity
  • Inspiratory reserve volume 

(Mnemonic: TIMM increases in pregnancy)

questions.text: Radiograph of a child with history of delayed walking showed the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiological features are suggestive of active rickets. The X-ray shows characteristic fraying and cupping of the metaphysis with widening of joint spaces.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: Which one of the following has maximum ionization potential?
questions.solution:
Helium ion has the maximum ionizing potential. It is similar to alpha particles, with two protons and two neutrons.

It has the least penetrating ability and penetrates only superficial tissues to an extent of 1 mm.

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presenting with halitosis and regurgitation, underwent a barium swallow scan as shown below. Weakness located in which of the following muscles predisposes to the suspected condition​?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a patient with halitosis and regurgitation with the GIF of an X-ray showing the barium swallow filling a sac in the posterior pharyngeal wall is highly suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. It protrudes through the Killian's dehiscence, a potential space present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus and the lower cricopharyngeus. The cricopharyngeus muscle is divisible into the superficial oblique component (pars oblique) and the deeper transverse component (pars fundiformis). These 2 components of the muscle have a potential space between them termed Killian's dehiscence.  

As a result of the uncoordinated contraction between the cricopharyngeus and upper oesophagal sphincter, mucosal herniation through the Killian's dehiscence gives rise to Zenker's diverticulum. This diverticulum is a common site for food impaction and accumulation (halitosis, regurgitation) and may cause dysphagia in affected patients. 

Note - Another potential site of diverticulum formation is the Laimer's triangle, situated below the cricopharyngeus and above the longitudinal fibres of the oesophagus. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: During a routine dissection class, your professor asks you to identify the structures seen in the given specimen. Correctly match the following with their respective structures:

choices.text: 1- Putamen; 2- Globus pallidus; 3- Caudate nucleus; 4- Thalamus
1- Caudate nucleus; 2- Thalamus; 3- Globus pallidus; 4- Putamen
1- Thalamus; 2- Caudate nucleus; 3- Globus pallidus; 4- Putamen
1- Caudate nucleus; 2- Putamen; 3- Thalamus; 4- Globus pallidus

questions.solution:
The given image shows the coronal section of the brain with different parts of the basal ganglia. The correct match is: 1- Caudate nucleus, 2- Thalamus, 3- Globus pallidus, 4- Putamen.

The basal ganglia constitutes the accessory motor system that functions in close association with the cerebral cortex and corticospinal motor control system. On each side of the brain, these ganglia consist of the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen 

The internal capsule separates the thalamus and the caudate nucleus from the lentiform nucleus. The caudate nucleus is a C-shaped mass of grey matter. It is divided into a head, body, and tail. Degeneration of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington's disease. 

Putamen lies medial  the external capsule, lies lateral to the globus pallidus. It receives fibers from the striatum and subthalamic nuclei. It acts as the main output of the basal ganglia to the thalamus and superior colliculus. The substantia nigra is seen in each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri. The levels of dopamine in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in parkinsonism disease.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought to her pediatrician with complaints of repeated hand wringing movements and finger-licking.  On examination, microcephaly and marked regression of language milestones were noticed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This girl with stereotyped hand-wringing movements, repetitive behaviour, regressed language milestones, and microcephaly most likely has Rett syndrome.

It is an X-linked dominant disease caused by a mutation of MECP2 gene and hence predominantly seen in girls. The onset is after a few months of apparently normal development.

Between the ages of 6 months to 2 years, affected children develop progressive encephalopathy. Patients typically have

  • Regression of previously acquired milestones following a period of normal development. This can include motor and language milestones.
  • Stereotypic hand movements such as hand wringing, biting, or licking the fingers, and poor muscle coordination.
  • Head circumference is normal at birth, but between the age of 6 months to 1 year, growth begins to decelerate leading to microcephaly. Seizures are an associated feature in a large number of cases. 

Supportive treatment is given. Physiotherapy is beneficial for muscular dysfunction. Anticonvulsants may be required to control seizures.

Other options:

Option A: Social anxiety disorder also known as social phobia is a fear of social situations like social gatherings, oral presentations, and meeting new people. They are fearful of embarrassing themselves in such situations.

Option B: Asperger's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. There is marked nonverbal communicative gestures and failure to develop relationships with peers. No significant delay in language milestones or cognitive development is seen. The intelligence remains normal.

Option D: Heller's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. It is also known as childhood disintegrative disorder. It is predominantly seen in boys. They have marked regression in intellectual, social, and language functions after 2 years of apparently normal development.

questions.text: Preoperative fasting recommendation is _________

choices.text: 2 hours for clear liquids in adults
2 hours for breast milk in infants

questions.solution:
Preoperative fasting recommendation is 2 hours for liquids in adults.

Recommended Preoperative Fasting period:

  • For neonates and infants:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 4 hours for breast milk
    • 6 hours for solids and infant formula
  • For all above 1 year of age:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 6 hours for a light meal
    • 8 hours if the meal contains fried, fatty food

Preoperative fasting is intended to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: A female patient with fever and malar rashes was found to have vegetations on either side of the heart valves. What is the likely type of endocarditis seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The vegetations on both sides of the valves along with the history suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus are consistent with Libman Sacks Endocarditis.

Summary of salient features of vegetations in different endocarditis:

  Rheumatic heart disease Infective endocarditis Non-bacterial thrombotic or marantic endocarditis Libman Sacks endocarditis
Etiology Rheumatic heart disease Infective endocarditis Malignancy (M3-AML, pancreatic carcinoma),
deep vein thrombosis,
Trousseau syndrome		 Systemic lupus erythematosus
Vegetations Small, warty, Firm, Friable Large, Bulky, friable, destructive Small, single, or multiple, non-destructive Small to medium-sized, flat, verrucous
Site Along lines of closure Cusps of valves, mural endocardium Line of closure Either or both sides of the valve leaflets.
Sterile/Infective Non-sterile Non-sterile Sterile Sterile
Embolization Uncommon Very common common Uncommon

Related Pearl: Vegetations in Various Types of Endocarditis

questions.text: Parents of a child with febrile seizures are concerned about the relapse, complications, and treatment of this condition. All of the following are true regarding the risks and management of this case, except:

choices.text: Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of a recurrent febrile seizure
Clobazam or clonazepam help reduce recurrence of febrile seizures
Anti-epileptic therapy can decrease the risk of future epilepsy
Pre-existing neurodevelopmental abnormality increases the risk of febrile seizures

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true, except for option C: Antiepileptic therapy can decrease the risk of future epilepsy. The risk of future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.

Febrile seizures are seizures that:

  • Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  • Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  • Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.

Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizures.

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
 Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy are 6%

Investigations:

  • In first episode of febrile seizure, lumbar puncture is indicated in cases of clinically suspected meningitis.
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Treatment:

An acute episode of seizure is terminated by intravenous lorazepam or midazolam. Antipyretics and proper hydration.

Prophylaxis:

  • In children with risk factors for recurrence or those with frequent recurrences (≥3 in 6 months or ≥4 in one year),give intermittent prophylaxis for 3 days during the fever episode to reduces recurrences.

Note:

  • Antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but do not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.
  • Intermittent oral nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam help reduce but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.
  • The risk of future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.
  • Pre-existing neurodevelopmental abnormality increases the risk of febrile seizures.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with complaints of excessive lacrimation. Ocular examination showed an abnormality similar to what is shown below. Which of the following organism is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Herbert's pits. This finding is seen in trachoma which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the TRIC (trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis) serovars A, B, Ba, C. 

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage.

The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms). Examination findings at this stage show: 

  • Conjunctival follicles containung Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes)
  • corneal Herbert's follicles (similar to conjunctival follicles)

Cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. And when the chronic infection with sequelae sets in, the patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia and later blurring, and finally loss of vision. Conjunctiva shows concretions (whitish deposits of inspissated mucus in depressions called glands of Henle). Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal which are remnants of healed of Herbert follicles)
  • corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

There can be associated trichiasis ( when at least one eyelash rubs the eyeball) and entropion.

At present WHO grading with `FISTO’ is in use.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

Strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (1–9 yrs)

  • Prevalence >10% → SAFE
  • 5 to 10% → FE
  • < 5% → NO intervention

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Halberstaedter–Prowazek bodies

 Trachoma 
Miyagawa bodies Lymphogranuloma venereum 
Levinthal–Cole–Lillie bodies Psittacosis
Leishman–Donovan bodies Kala-azar 
Negri bodies Rabies
Guarnieri bodies Vaccinia
Bollinger bodies Fowl pox
Henderson–Peterson bodies Molluscum contagiosum 
Cowdry type-A bodies Yellow fever, Herpes virus infection 
Cowdry type-B bodies Adenovirus, poliovirus
Rusell bodies Multiple myeloma 
Aschoff bodies Rheumatic fever 
Call–Exner bodies Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary 
Civatte (colloid) bodies Lichen planus 
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies Malakoplakia 
Lewy bodies Parkinson's disease 
Pappenheimer bodies Non-heme iron pigments in siderocytes 
Howell–Jolly bodies Splenectomy, Megaloblastic Anemia, Hemolytic anemia 
Heinz bodies G-6-PD deficiency 
Gamna–Gandy bodies Congestive splenomegaly 
Mallory bodies Hyaline inclusions in hepatocytes seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis
Councilman bodies Hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis, seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.
Psammoma bodies Dystrophic calcification in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenoma of ovary & papillary carcinoma of thyroid, papillary type of renal cell carcinoma.
Donovan bodies Granuloma inguinale 
Nissl's bodies Cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons 
Mooser bodies Typhus fever
Creola bodies Asthma 
Verocay bodies Schwannoma 
Schiller–Duval bodies Endodermal sinus tumor

Ferruginous bodies

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented to OPD with the given presentation. On examination, it seems gelatinous in consistency. She reports fluctuation in size, mild numbness in hand and occasional pain. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history and image are suggestive of a patient with a ganglion cyst. 

Ganglion cyst arises from the leakage of synovial fluid from a joint or tendon sheath and thus contains a glary, viscous fluid.

It can appear anywhere in the wrist but the most common area is the dorsal surface of the scapholunate ligament.

Patients usually present with painless, well-defined, cystic, transillumination-positive, and non-tender swelling. If there is an impingement on a nearby nerve or structure it can cause pain.

It disappears spontaneously, but the aspiration of the swelling or operative removal can be done for reassurance or when there is pressure on the nerve. Even if treatment is done, the rates of recurrence are high.  

Other Options:

Option B: Lipomas are benign tumors of adipose tissue. It can occur anywhere and at any depth. It can be encapsulated or diffuse, superficial or deep. On examination, they are nontender and non-pulsatile. Because of the soft consistency, they may appear to be fluctuant but they are not. The slip sign is positive.

Option C: Dermoid Cyst presents as asymptomatic, slowly enlarging, painless, superficial localized swellings over the volar aspect of the hand, especially the distal portion of the digits.

Option D: An extremity hematoma is a localized collection of blood in the soft tissues of an extremity, typically occurring after trauma, surgery, or in patients with bleeding disorders. The hematoma can develop in various tissue planes: subcutaneous, intramuscular, or subfascial compartments.

questions.text: A young female patient from a rural area presented with severe pain in the lower abdomen and pelvic regions, and vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period was 2 months back and her urine pregnancy test appeared positive. The physician suspects a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Blood is most likely to collect in :
questions.solution:
The physician can confirm the diagnosis by obtaining the blood from the rectouterine pouch, which is also called as the pouch of Douglas. This procedure is called culdocentesis.

The classic triad of symptoms in tubal pregnancy are

  • Severe lower abdominal pain
  • Amenorrhea- usually for 6-8 weeks before the appearance of the symptoms
  • Vaginal bleeding

If a ruptured ectopic pregnancy is suspected, then blood samples should be sent for hemoglobin estimation and blood grouping. Estimation of β-HCG can be used to confirm pregnancy. Once it is suspected, transvaginal sonography or laparoscopy can be performed to visualize the ruptured ectopic.

However, if imaging techniques are not available, then culdocentesis can be performed. An 18 gauge lumbar puncture needle with a syringe is inserted into the rectouterine pouch by puncturing the posterior fornix. If non-clotting blood is obtained from the pouch which has a hematocrit of more than 15%, it indicates the presence of ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

Peritoneum of the female pelvis

In females, the peritoneum covers the anterior and anterolateral surfaces of the rectum, uterus, and urinary bladder. Spaces found in the female pelvis are:

Pararectal fossae- Present on either side of the rectum. They are limited laterally by the peritoneum that covers the uterosacral ligaments. 

Paravesical fossae- Present on either side of the bladder. It is limited laterally by the peritoneum which covers the round ligament of the uterus.

Rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas)- The peritoneum which covers the anterior surface of the rectum is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterior surface of the posterior fornix of the vagina and the uterus, forming a rectouterine pouch.

Vesicouterine pouch- The peritoneum covering the fundus and body of the uterus, is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder forming a vesicouterine pouch.

Ovarian fossa- is a shallow depression in the peritoneal lining of the lateral pelvic wall between the peritoneal ridges. It is formed by the obliterated umbilical arteries anteriorly, the ureter posteriorly, and the external iliac vessels above. It lies behind the lateral attachment of the broad ligament and contains the ovary in nulliparous females.

questions.text: A person has been bitten by the following snake. Which of the following options describes the symptoms seen classically in this snake bite?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows common krait, which is neurotoxic and shows classical symptoms such as muscle paralysis.

The neurotoxicity symptoms that would be seen in the patient include: 

  • headache
  • blurred vision
  • perioral paraesthesia
  • hyperacusis
  • dizziness
  • vertigo
  • gooseflesh
  • vomiting
  • hypersalivation

Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

Other options:

Option A: Anaphylaxis is seen in poisoning due to stiletto snakes. Other symptoms include pain, swelling, blisters, and local lymph node enlargements.

Option B: Systemic bleeding such as intravascular hemolysis, ecchymosis, and incoagulable blood is seen in bites due to back-fanged snakes.

Option C: Myoglobinuria is seen in poisoning due to sea snakes.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Snake Toxicity Main features

Viperidae

  • Pit viper
  • Saw-scaled viper
 Vasculotoxic

Local reaction

  • severe
  • edema and necrosis

Anticoagulant effect - widespread bleeding

Elapidae

  • Cobra
  • Krait
 Neurotoxic

Local reaction

  • mild

Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (Sea snakes) are now considered subfamily of elapidae

 Myotoxic Generalized rhabdomyolysis

Saw scaled viper:

Green pit viper:

Common krait:

King cobra:

Sea snake:

questions.text: The sign given below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly). 

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • ectopia lentis
  • myopia
  • flat cornea
  • retinal detachments
  • early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • thoracic scoliosis
  • spontaneous pneumothorax
  • striae atrophicae in the skin

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist. Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist 

 

Diagnosis is based on criteria depending on the family history, aortic root X score, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and presence of FBN1 mutation.

Other options:

Option B: Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, the wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

Option D: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum is characterized by abnormal deposition of calcium in the elastic fibers of skin, eyes, and vessels.

questions.text: While performing an inguinal hernia repair on a 3-year-old boy, the surgeon notices a Meckel’s diverticulum as the content of the hernial sac. What is this hernia called?
questions.solution:
Meckel’s diverticulum found in inguinal or femoral hernial sacs is known as Littre's hernia. It can cause intestinal obstruction.

Option A: Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option B: Narath’s hernia is seen in patients with congenital dislocation of the hip. It is a femoral hernia seen behind the femoral vessels.

Option C: Cloquet’s hernia is a type of femoral hernia where the sac lies under the pectineus fascia.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face. Which among the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is nodular acne and the drug of choice for this condition is oral isotretinoin.

Isotretinoin is an orally administered systemic retinoid that is used in the management of severe acne.

Commonly seen adverse effects of isotretinoin are cheilitis (dry lips), xerosis (dry skin), xerostomia (dry mouth), dry nose, and increased sun sensitivity. 

Oral isotretinoin is contraindicated in pregnant patients and patients who may be pregnant. 

Other Options:

Option A: Steroids are not indicated in cases of acne as they can exacerbate the condition due to increased sebum production and skin cell turnover disruption.

Options B and C: Nodulocystic acne is a severe form of acne that often requires more aggressive treatment options, such as isotretinoin. While antibiotics may be used in some cases of nodulocystic acne, they are not the first-line treatment option.

Related Pearl: Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Image: Global Alliance Algorithm for Improving Outcomes in acne

BPO - Benzoyl peroxide

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve:

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug B is more efficacious than drug A

questions.solution:
The more the curve is to the left, the more is its potency. Hence drug B is the most potent on the given dose-response curve (DRC).

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • The more the curve is on the left side, the more is its potency.
  • Hence in the given DRC drug B is most potent and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve.

Hence in the given DRC, drug B has the least efficacy, and drugs A, C & D are equally efficacious.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn was brought with vomiting and diarrhea that developed since birth. On examination, the baby is jaundiced, hypotonic, and has hepatomegaly. Urine was positive for Benedict's test, blood glucose was low and erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate was elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly with elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant can't metabolize galactose 1-phosphate which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism (in females)

The presence of galactose in urine (Positive benedict's test), elevated blood galactose, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and prevention of complications is important.

Other options:

Option A: Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of fructokinase. There are no symptoms except for the benign excretion of fructose in urine. Inherited as autosomal recessive. 

Option B: Von Gierke's disease is due to glucose-6-phosphatase or translocase deficiency. It is a glycogen storage disorder (Type I).  They may develop hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis in the neonatal period, but hepatomegaly usually develops at 3–4 months. They may have doll-like facies, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen. Hyperuricemia, the elevation of triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins, and phospholipids are seen.

Option D: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to a deficiency of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase B). Patients are healthy and symptom-free until fructose or sucrose is ingested. Clinical manifestations may include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a painless beefy-red ulcer on the labia that bleeds when touched. There is no lymphadenopathy. Microscopic findings are as shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a painless, beefy red, foul-smelling ulcer with no lymphadenopathy, with microscopy showing Donovan bodies, points to a diagnosis of granuloma inguinale. It is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis also known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis.

The incubation period varies from 8-80 days, the average being 50 days.

Four types of lesions have been described in this condition:

  • Ulcerogranulomatous - most common type with painless beefy red ulcers. They are also highly vascular and bleed on touch.
  • Hypertrophic - usually with a raised irregular edge
  • Necrotic - offensive smelling ulcer that causes tissue destruction
  • Sclerotic or cicatricial - with fibrous or scar tissue

The image below shows a beefy-red ulcer characteristic of donovanosis.

Primary lesions can occur on genital and extragenital sites. Untreated genital ulcers are followed by genital disfigurement and have the potential for malignant change.

Prolonged treatment with antibiotics is generally advised for donovanosis, usually for a minimum period of 6 weeks.

Treatment ladder for Donovanosis

  • First line
    • Azithromycin 1 g orally on the first day followed by 500 mg daily
  • Second line
    • Doxycycline 100 mg orally on the first day followed by 100 mg twice daily (or) 
    • Co‐trimoxazole 960 mg twice daily

questions.text: An intern posted in the labor room is administering birth-dose vaccines to a newborn baby. According to the National Immunization Schedule, which of the following vaccine would he not administer?
questions.solution:
The pentavalent vaccine is not given at birth. The vaccines given at birth are BCG, OPV (0 dose) and hepatitis B vaccines.

Related Pearl: National Immunization Schedule (India)

questions.text: You are a physiologist, studying the microstructure of a skeletal muscle. In the image given below, all of the following can be found in the area marked 'x' except ______.
questions.solution:
The marked region 'x' is depicting the I-band of the myofibril. It does not contain myosin.

The portion of myofibril that lies between two Z lines is known as the sarcomere. One sarcomere comprises 1 entire A band and 2 half-I bands. 

A band consists of Myosin (thick filaments) surrounded by Actin filaments. I-band comprises thin filaments that contain actin, troponin, and tropomyosin. H zone is the middlemost part of the A band which comprises only myosin heads. During skeletal muscle contraction, A band remains constant. Z lines come closer to each other. H and I bands reduce in their lengths. 

Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.

Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

  • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that help to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: What type of data does the image given below represent?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a histogram. It is used to represent frequency distributions of continuous quantitative data.

Nominal and ordinal data can be represented by a bar chart.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A child presents with lesions as shown in the image below. He also complained of decreased vision at night. Which of the following dose of vitamin A prophylaxis given to children under the vitamin A distribution scheme in India could have prevented this condition?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU  given yearly between the ages 1-6 years
1,00,000 IU  given yearly between the ages 1-6 years
1,00,000 IU  given 6-monthly between the ages 1-6 years
2,00,000 IU given 6-monthly between the ages 1-6 years

questions.solution:
The image above showing phrynoderma along with the history of decreased vision at the night suggests a likely diagnosis of vitamin A deficiency. Under the vitamin-A distribution scheme in India, 200,000 IU of vitamin A are given orally at 6-monthly intervals between the ages of 1 to 6 years.

Vitamin A deficiency is a major preventable cause of blindness in children. It can lead to mucocutaneous disease and result in various ocular complications, including blindness. The earliest sign of vitamin A deficiency is defective dark adaptation and night blindness (nyctalopia). Xerosis and scaling are commonly present in cutaneous findings. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by the presence of keratotic follicular papules over anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms is also seen.

Treatment is done by administering 50,000–2,00,000 IU of daily vitamin A supplementation until clinical signs and symptoms resolve and serum retinol levels normalize. 

The image below shows a Bitot's spot(due to Vitamin A deficiency) seen as a foamy appearance on the surface of the conjunctiva.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinol palmitate.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic, with a history of binge drinking and multiple episodes of vomiting, presents with hematemesis and abdominal pain. On endoscopy, a longitudinal mucosal tear is found in the gastroesophageal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a Mallory-Weiss tear. 

Mallory-Weiss tear is a longitudinal tear in the mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction.

It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Management of Mallory Weiss tear

  1. Conservative, as it is usually self-limiting.
  2. Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy.
  3. Angiographic embolization - if endoscopy fails.
  4. High gastrotomy - if all these maneuvers fail.

Option A: Boerhaave syndrome is characterized by spontaneous perforation of the esophagus. Here all layers are involved. Clinical features include Mackler's triad

  • Retching
  • Chest pain
  • Subcutaneous emphysema

Option C: Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE) is characterized by dilated venules in the submucosa of the antrum.

On endoscopy: Watermelon stomach.

Management of GAVE

  • Endoscopic argon photocoagulation (APC)
  • If persistent - antrectomy.

Option D: Dieulafoy lesion is a vascular malformation (dilated submucosal arterioles) that is seen along the lesser curvature of the stomach. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Management of Dieulafoy lesion: 

  • Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy
  • Angiographic embolization.

questions.text: What is the earliest sign seen on cystoscopy in a patient suspected to have bladder tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is the pallor of the mucosa around the ureteric orifice due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen.

In long-standing cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced (thimble bladder). This is managed by augmentation cystoplasty.

The following X-ray KUB shows a thimble bladder:


Ureteric lesions can also be seen in genitourinary tuberculosis. They include:

  • Kerr’s kink - kinking of the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ)
  • Ureteral stricture
  • Beaded ureter
  • Shortening of the ureter
  • Golf hole ureter - Longitudinal fibrosis leading to shortening of the ureter and pulling up the orifice as a gaping hole. Reimplantation of ureter is done.
